Situation1: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: They are expected at routine meetings that occur frequently
Story: The phone pressed against my ear, I listened as Mr. Harris, a long-time customer, unleashed his frustration about the new offer I was supposed to sell. “How can you justify this price hike?” he demanded, his voice trembling with anger. As a telemarketer, I was trained to handle objections, to stay calm, to explain every detail until the customer felt heard. But as he pressed for more and more information, I glanced at the clock—ten minutes until my advocacy meeting, one I couldn’t afford to miss. My supervisor expected me to be present at every session, to represent our clients without fail. The pressure built in my chest. If I cut Mr. Harris short, I’d betray the trust I’d built with him and fail my telemarketing duties. If I stayed, I’d be late to the meeting, letting down my advocacy team and possibly missing crucial updates for my client. My mind raced, torn between the voice on the phone and the ticking clock, each role demanding my full attention, neither willing to wait.
